title: How many seats in the Chamber of Deputies will the Five Star Movement and any pre-election coalition partners win in the next Italian general election?
preds: Thought I saw forecast of 222-224 seats (Reuters). Have never really understood Italian elections though ;)
Oops seems to be certainty now
Late to this one. Was going to be 95% based on consensus but went 100% instead given that.
Don’t believe the number is known yet but believe I saw a forecast in the 230 range.
Well if its not being closed I'm going to answer.

German language: https://derstandard.at/2000075457018/Die-Ergebnisse-der-italienschen-Wahlen
Italian language: http://www.repubblica.it/speciali/politica/elezioni2018/2018/03/06/news/elezioni_2018_il_calcolo_dei_seggi_nel_proporzionale_per_il_m5s_altri_133_deputati-190563291/?ref=RHPPTP-BL-I0-C12-P1-S1.12-T1 32,7% => 221 sedi

The question at this point is whether the Five Star Movement form a coalition with Salvini and Berlusconi's coalition. No one got enough votes to be the clear leader alone.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43272700
Five Star Movement is expected to emerge as the largest single party in Italy's lower house, with 216-236 seats - http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43272700

- M5S with 32.2% of the vote
- Seats are awarded by a complex system involving both direct constituencies and proportional representation.
- Projections have M5S as by far the largest single party with 231 seats
Looks like anti-establishment is the way to go this year...... Drain the swamp!
MS5 doing better than I thought. I don’t understand Italian voting well enough to understand if capturing 1/3 of votes translates closely to 1/3 of seats (210 of 630). But I’ll go for it...

M5S ca. 31,6% -> 196-246 seats ,
I have to double check my old calculation.

Italy’s anti-establishment 5-Star Movement was set to get the most seats of any party in the lower house of parliament, but fall short of a majority, after a national election on Sunday, according to a vote projection released by RAI state TV. According to the projection, which was based on votes counted as of 0230 GMT on Monday, the movement founded as a protest party in 2009 could expect to get 216-236 seats in the 630-seat lower house. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-election-projection-lowerhouse/all-groups-short-of-majority-in-italys-lower-house-seat-projection-idUSKBN1GH09G?il=0

Too late to make a difference, but it looks like M5S could get more than 200 seats, based on the first exit polls (which have often been inaccurate in the past). 00:07 First seat projections Below are the first seat projections from public broadcaster Rai. Because the election this year used a new and untested electoral law, and some seats are allocated through proportional representation and others through first-past-the-post, all projections should be taken with a pinch of salt. Rai's figures for the Chamber of Deputies (Lower House):
Centre-right coalition:225-265
Centre-left: 115-155
Five Star Movement: 195-235
Free and Equal: 12-20
Others: 6-8
Latest predictions from exit polls put M5S between 216 and 236 seats !! Flipping...
Got overexcited by the (historically unreliable) exit polls. And a new electoral system makes predictions even less solid. So returning to halfway between my previous positions.
Final forecast to reflect the reasonably stable positions of the parties in the polls.
I wish I could say I've been following this one but the elections are too depressingly right wing

Affirming my 29 Jan forecast, to add some commentary. http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/16059870.David_Pratt__The_dark_spectre_of_racism_is_haunting_the_Italian_elections/?ref=ebln "With around 600,000 refugees and migrants having landed on Italian shores during the last four years, hostility towards migrants and fears over growing multi-ethnicity continue to fuel Italy’s populist political forces in an election campaign stalked by racism and xenophobia. “Italians First” has fast become the defining mantra of Sunday’s election, with both the Northern League, the populist Five Star Movement (M5S) led by Luigi Di Maio and Mr Berlusconi’s Forza Italia all echoing each others’ calls for action against migrants. It was just over a year ago that Northern League leader Matteo Salvini called for a “mass cleansing of Italy, street by street, neighbourhood by neighbourhood, square by square, and through the use of force if need be.........................Should the outcome of the election require the centre-right to do a deal to form a government, no doubt Silvio Berlusconi will be there to act as kingmaker. And as if that thought were not depressing enough, news yesterday that Donald Trump’s former White House strategist Steve Bannon was on his way to Rome to provide support for Mr Salvini is even further cause for concern. Frankly, it’s the last thing Italy needs right now.”

Trending into the last polls, undecided voters were 50% of the vote.  Late deciders usually break significantly against established parties.  Five stars current softening of positions is smart politics, meant to make the party more acceptable to timid voters; hardline 5 star voters have nowhere to go; there is no downside.  Illegal immigration with resulting unemployment is pushing people to vote, I do not believe it will be an apathetic turnout among 5 star voters.  That said, the rosatelllum's implications will penalize 5Star regional and proportional voting. However, the greater the voting percentage, the less the effective penalty.   The 3% threshold will ameliorate this a small amount.  The largest result of the current rules is that italy will have unified opposition and a fractured unstable government.   5star is the clearest vote for eurosceptism and one of two votes for italian nationalism.  I think 5 star is going to out perform the vote on italian islands and south.  Chamber of deputies has 630.  Of these 12 are elected by expats, none of which will go 5 Star. 
Lets divide the electorate into two haves - the 50% that are already decided, and the 50% that are undecided. So 309 multiplied by 27.5 (last poll) yields roughly 86 deputies. 
To get 201 votes,  5Star only needs to win 37% of the electorate.    This is a very volatile election - there is way more than a 10% chance 5 star will hit that target, even with proportionality penalties.  Alternate scenario: 2/3 of voters set, 1/3 uncertain.
116 delegates.  What percent does five star have to get to get to 201 = 41.4 % of the vote undecided vote.  Undecided voters represent a huge swing to the upside, which will benefit Berlesconi's party and 5 star.

Some of my peers have put a great deal of thought into this. I do wonder if apathy may play a role here. Regardless, “heavy” on the 88-200 category
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/27/there-is-no-long-term-vision-young-italians-lose-faith-in-politics

Aggregating polls from January through mid-February (none permitted in the last 2 weeks up to elections in Italy), then multiplying their standard deviation by 3 to account for large expected volatility and large percentage of undecided voters.

A coalition before the election is increasingly unlikely. I believe the "first past post" constituencies will return 5 Star deputies as if there was still proportional representation and 5 star's percentage of the popular vote was approx 10% less.
 So around 155 Deputies if polls are correct and 5 Star gets %28 of the popular vote.
Not a single opinion poll has it outside this range in 6 months and most close to the middle.
It is gaining strength and has a message that is resonating. It is not going to lose seats.
This is assuming they do not form a coalition with anyone before the election.  This also assumes a strong push by the Center Right before the election.
Being that they hold at about 30%... getting 30 of seats sounds feasible... ...
Taking a rough consensus position until I look into this a bit more
Heading higher because M5S is still the leading party in the polls.

Continued unhappiness with the state of Italian economics, and its relationship to the EU, as well as concerns about immigration will work in favor of Gold Star, as well as right wing parties like Forza Italia.

Italy heading for hung parliament (or very broad coalition)
Corriere della Sera English
According to IPSOS opinion poll for Corriere della Sera, centre-right expected to win 283 seats, 5-Star Movement (M5S) 152, and centre-left 158, with support for Democratic Party (PD) still falling. Emma Bonino's +Europa party expected to exceed 3% ...

Latest polls Five Star Movement (M5S) is expected to get 27.8 percent. While the anti-establishment group is the leading single party, it would need to make alliances to form a government, an option it has so far refused to consider. The left-wing coalition, which includes the ruling Democratic Party, is predicted to come a close third with 27.4 percent of the vote.
Seeking government may lead to coalition choices that ensure the popular vote this time reflects the number of deputies.

A recent large forecast has M5S just over 200 seats, but the general recent average is for them to have around 150, so I've upped the probability for over 200 seats accordingly (allowing for some momentum behind M5S) while still keeping 88-200 the most likely possibility.

Adjusting based on recent polls and today's news of possible broken financial promises by 5-Star parliamentarians.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-election-5-star/italys-5-star-movement-under-fire-over-missing-funds-idUSKCN1FX29A
Assuming they can Form a coalition with either FI or PD
Fine tuning for potential to exceed 200 - but likely still in 100-200 range.

Calculating 95 percent confidence intervall for the polls of the last months (according to: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election,_2018; upper margin of error 189, lower margin of error 143), adjusting qualitatively for momentum and the probability of major blows of M5 performance, e.g. scandals that resonate with the electorate - taking into account that there are only four weeks left.

There had been some interesting isssues in italy in the last days::
M5S near to 30%:
https://www.centrometeoitaliano.it/attualita/sondaggi-elettorali-elezioni-politiche-2018-le-intenzioni-di-voto-della-settimana-59090/?refresh_cens m5s has a new person, an ex-model with political knowledge:
http://www.ilmessaggero.it/primopiano/politica/m5s_alessia_dalessandro_coordino_22_commissioni_cdu_voglio_occuparmi_giovani_espatriati-3524185.html
And  a racist attack: http://www.repubblica.it/cronaca/2018/02/04/news/raid_macerata_traini_portato_in_carcere_montacuto-187998751/?ref=RHPPLF-BH-I0-C8-P1-S2.5-T1

Based on polling from multiple sources, FSM will capture a significant number of seats. The polling is also supported by the current situation in Europe and Italy. Multiple European countries have seen a rise by anti-immigrant right wing groups and in some cases, these organizations have captured the majority in government. Italy has been inundated with refugees and unfortunately have a history of reacting negatively to foreigners. The combination of polling and subjective anecdotes support significant gains for FSM in the next election.

Adjusting from the 90% I had on 03 Jan, for passage of time. All recent projections are well within the 88-200 range. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election,_2018 Date	Polling firm		M5S	
25 Jan 2018	Piepoli		159	
25 Jan 2018	YouTrend	155	
22-25 Jan 2018	Ixè		177	
22 Jan 2018	Piepoli		159

17-19 Jan 2018	Ixè		161	
18 Jan 2018	Ipsos		170

6 Jan 2018	YouTrend		140	
1 Jan 2018	YouTrend		157

155 is the current projection.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election,_2018#2018_2 That seems well short of 200, so it is likely to be in the 88-200 bracket.

Average of the number of seats M5S will receive in the March election based on the Wikipedia data on seat projections for CoD is 166 seats. Hence in the 88<x<200 bracket. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election,_2018#2018_2

The obvious thing to note is that a new electoral system was brought in just a couple of months ago, making comparison with previous elections fairly difficult. The new law is summarised here: https://globalriskinsights.com/2017/11/italy-rosatellum-bis-primer/
The key features are:
- There will be 630 Deputies elected to the Chamber
- A PR/FPTP split, with 37% of the Deputies elected on FPTP (232) and 61% on PR (386). (12 Deputies are also elected to represent overseas populations)
- The country is split into 20 constituencies with a varying number of Deputies elected What this will mean:
- Parties with both a strong local base and high overall voting percentages will do well
- Parties in coalition will do better in the FPTP part of the election, as they avoid splitting their vote With all that in mind, we should also note that the 5SM opposed this system strongly as they both reject the idea of pre-election coalitions and their vote is spread fairly evenly rather than concentrated in certain parts of the country. It was felt that this would harm their chances under the new electoral system. With all that in mind, the polling indicates (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election,_2018)
 that the 5SM:
- will win c. 28% of the vote in the PR elections. This would translate into around 109 seats.
- will win c. 28% of the vote in the FPTP elections, well behind the centre-right coalition who are above 35%. If this were proportional, it would mean 65 seats. The 5SM have previously performed well in Liguria, Marche, Sardinia and Sicily, while performing worse in Trentino, Lombardy and Campania. It shoudl be noted that the two largest constituencies in the country are Lobardy and Campania, where 5SM perform poorly, while Liguria, Sardinia and Marche are all among the smallest. This does suggest that the they should do worse than their voting share indicates for the FPTP section indicates. From a base figure of 174, we can correct downwards for their vote spread to c.154. We can correct up a couple for the overseas seat allocation to c.156. Changes in political opinion and potential polling inaccuracies provide a level of volatility, which will mean a not insignificant chance of divergence from 156 seats.
consensus aka I have no idea

Out of actual forecast voter survey I calculated between 169 and177 seats for 5 stelle:

A sure sign you’re a threat in politics? You get mentioned a lot even when the article isn’t about you. Note the attacks from left and centre on the Five Star Movement. Do Italians really want the return of Berlusconi and his bonga bonga parties?  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/23/italy-elections-as-left-splinters-berlusconi-waits-in-wings

5 Star currently at 170 seats projected.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election,_2018#Chamber_of_Deputies This far out from an election, this is meaningless since many voters make last minute decisions.

Slightly reducing uncertainty as the election draws closer, but leaving open the possibility of a late surge for M5S. The most recent projection has M5S on 170 seats, a slight uptick, but not significant for these purposes. Looking forward, perhaps it's easier to see a right-wing surge, in that Forza Italia and co. are possibly the only ones capable of forming a government, which would perhaps hurt M5S more in the FPTP seats, but leave them in the 88-200 range.
Rising dissatisfaction of Italians with status quo
Don’t underestimate the example US election has provided Europe. Populism is in.

in the last general elections M5S refrained from taking over responsibility to govern. they now also have declined to any potential partnering. as the acting characters have changed since the last elections there may be a chance (e.g. 25%) that the party is changing its stance short-term. the impetus to form a coalition, however, will most likely come depend on the chance to gain a majority. given the political tendency of the parties above 3% i only take into account Lega Nord and the Fratelli. i am weighting the likelihoods by ignoring any statistical dependency between the outcomes. this is mathematically incorrect (but easy to do), for which i apologise.

Italy - legally required to hold a general election in 2018. The populist Five Star government finished third in the 2013 general election and has seen strong support in resent polling. 
Youthful new comer and groomed leader Daio won with 83 percent of the vote and the only people that could win against him decided not to run against him.
There support basis seams to be established and seams to be happy. The proof of that is the winnig local elections in such important cities as Turin or Milan. I can see it growth to around 100 seats.

Recently there has been a corruption case raised against M5S. Increasing the 50<x<87 bracket and decreaseing x<340 bracket  https://jacobinmag.com/2018/01/italian-election-berlusconi-five-star-movement

In the December opinion polls, M5S polls about 28% on average (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election%2C_2018#2018_2). This should be enough for about 120 out of the 398 proportional seats. Can they get 80+ out of the 230 first-past-the post seats? The first-past-the-post system rewards large parties with widespread popularity, which is good for M5S. However, if the center-right coalition wants to have any chance to govern, they should agree in advance to coordinate in the run for the first-past-the post seats. This would sharply reduce the M5S advantage.
Growing support and more mainstream campaigning will raise their profile but a true landslide seems out of reach

Movimento Cinque Stelle is remaining true to its political identity as a "pure" opposition movement by not forming a pre election coalition. M5S's anti establishment populist identity and message appeals successfully to eurosceptics, and a youthful, disenfranchised population.  However the political culture and nature of politics in Italy ultimately necessitates and encourages coalition formation. It seems that M5S has painted itself into a corner with its message eventhough Luigi Di Maio is putting forth a slicker and slightly more moderate image.  The only problem is this message may start overlapping with the right-wing Forza, League and a potential centrist PD coalition who have more regional ties and historically a more persistent culturally ingrained message. Berlusconi, a master at coalition formation, will absorb centrists falling away from the PD coalition.
M5S is doing well in the national polling however, the new election law allows only one pick on each ballot. It is quite possible that people with regional interests will forgo the M5S candidate and stay with their regional alliances. M5S will not live up to expectations in the first-past-the-post ballot.
   If M5S starts polling a few points over 32% I will have to think about revising upward but I think that any coalition Berlusconi creates will prevail in the elections and capture the largest segment of the population which is between the ages of 40 and 54.  
"Old age and treachery will always beat youth and exuberance."
If anything, M5S seems to be gaining in the December polls  (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election%2C_2018)

On recent polling, M5S score around 25-30%, giving 100-119 of the proportionally allocated seats in the chamber of deputies. Using the cube rule, the FPTP seats should be 63 for their current polling of 28%. Given that a simulation online gives 46 FPTP seats, they are clearly unfavourably distributed. But taking a simple multiplier as a first approximation of this bad distribution, this gives 31-88 FPTP seats in this same range, giving a total of 131-207 seats. So it is clear high probability should go the 88-200 range, but allowance should be made for late polling shifts and the uncertainty inherent in a new system with majoritarian aspects.
Five Star Movement will rise, like all populist movements across Europe, but not to more than 200 deputies.

M5S might come out stronger than expected: This dynamic will triggered by the slow, but steady decline of PD in the polls which leads many voters to strategically opt for M5S instead of the left coalition, out of fear that the Berlusconi/Salvini-team might otherwise win in a landslide.

The entry thresholds and the partial FPTP system explicitly encourage parties to enter into coalition agreements before the elections. Parties risk being marginalised when they fail in the FPRP districts and win only a fraction of the PR seats, or, even worse, fail to cross the thresholds. Moreover, the 10% hurdle that is set for coalitions suggests that smaller parties have little option but to join either the centre-left bloc (CSX) or the centre-right bloc (CDX). And what about Five Star? It’s evident that the electoral system was designed to hurt them, not the centre-left. This is still true. The party doesn’t have a strong local base yet and rules out to form any alliances with other parties, which have shaped the political system it denounces. So they are likely to go it alone, even as it hurts their prospects. Five Star currently polls at around 28%: the highest of any individualparty but not enough to get behind the steering wheel.
https://economics.rabobank.com/publications/2017/december/italy-cyclical-upswing--what-will-2018-bring/ 29.0
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election,_2018 Coalition vote is the same, but centre left and centre right will take 26 and 36.6% respectively.  Chamber of Deputies has 630 seats. 5 Star currently holds 88 seats. 29% of 630 = 182.7 seats
The Party seems to be gaining popularity but major changes seem to take time...I believe they will make progress but not "takeover" just yet
Populist parties have gained votes all over Europe. but they wer not able to get majorities. In Italy the five Star movement is  strong, but not that strong.

They'll do well as I think Italy, more then other 'major' countries in the EU is in a position of susceptibility to the populism movement (which I believe is what the 5-Star party represents). Not a lot going on industry-wise, and a country that has generally always been held in high esteem, except for recently. That being said, I think the movement will be somewhat hampered, with the most notorious populist campaign continuously getting bad press.

The Five Star Movement appears to have a stronger hand than before. Given their current 88 seats, that would argue then for an improved position coming out of the forthcoming elections.
https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/897654/Italy-election-eurosceptic-parties-polls-Five-Star-Movement-EU
They won 103 seats in 2013 and seem to have struck the appropriate anti-two party balance in a country that's proud but not hard nationalists.
I have no knowledge on which to base a forecast.

March 4th is seen as the most likely date for the 2018 elections to take place. While M5S position has stayed stable with the party enjoying the support of 28,3% of the voters, they still have not (and according to a expert whom I talked to will not) form a coalition before the election to go into the vote as likely winners of the election. I stick to my previous prediction that with that support number and decision not to form a coalition they will secure ca. 150 seats at the CoD. I have thus increased the percentage points of 88<x<200 to 80%. The stable 28% support makes it more and more unlikely that M5S will secure less than 88 votes in the upcoming elections. Thus I have decreased the likelihood of the two lower brackets. Italian political experts predict Berlusconi to be a king maker in the next government and talk of a centre-right coalition possible victory. Others predict a hung parliament initially after the elections as no party is likely to achieve more than 40% of the overall vote.
https://www.cnbc.com/2017/12/15/italy-elections-likely-to-result-in-worst-outcome-of-a-hung-parliament.html

According to polls they should score around 200 seats. But it seems enthusiasm for radical parties has lightly passed its zenith. And the new electoral system seems to be biased against the Five Star Movement. Unless Beppe makes a surprise deal before the elections he is not going to reach the 200 mark. Below 88 is impossible, 5 star is way to popular to score that low.
Fear of Silvio will produce hope for change.

There are 630 seats in the Chamber of Deputies. Currently the Five Star Movement has 88 seats. Italy's economy and politics will remain largely unreformed. There will remain lots of discontent and people who feel that mainstream parties have little to offer them. I find it reasonable to think that the Five Star Movement will increase slightly in popularity but not massively so.

I think that to receive less than 88 seats, they would have to do much worse than current polling indicates or they would have to be crushed by an alliance of other parties that gained 40 % of the vote, which alliance currently does not exist. Besides, Forza Italia and Lega Nord together wouldn't very likely reach 40 %.

There is an indication that Silvio Berlusconi might be making a come back into politics as the head of the right wing coalition. While it is no certainty the right wing coalition seems to be one of the more likely ones that could both form a coalition ahead of election and thus receive the 40% of vote to achieve majority in the parliament. 
https://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2017/1206/Berlusconi-s-improbable-return-to-politics-Why-Italy-is-giving-him-another-look
The centre-right coalition had strong results in the Sicily regional vote managing an almost 40% of the total vote. M5S came second achieving 34,5% of the votes. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sicilian_regional_election,_2017
Looking back at the last parliamentary elections it clearly shows that Sicily is one of the regions in Italy that is divided amongst center-right coalition voters and M5S voters.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_general_election,_2013#/media/File:Italian_2013_elections.png However I see M5S insistence on not forming a coalition with any other party as their weakness in the upcoming parliamentary elections. While they are clearly the most popular party overall in Italy at the moment, it is unlikely they will manage to receive a majority of the vote (40%) on their own. Looking at it is possible that they will be defeated by some sort of multi-party coalition - currently is most likely to be that of the center-right. Hence I have adjusted my prediction increasing the likelihood of M5S receiving votes in the 50-87 and 88-200 brackets.

It seems clear MS5 will not lose any one of their current 83 seats, with a 95% chance of increasing seats up to 340. There is frustration with the status quo, but to get above 340 seats would be nearly 4x their current allocation.

The 2018 Italian general election is due to be held no later than 20 May 2018, that is to say no later than the last Sunday of the seventy days after the natural expiration of the current five-year parliamentary term on 15 March 2018.  Voters will elect the 630 members of the Chamber of Deputies and the 315 elective members of the Senate of the Republic for the 18th term of the Italian Parliament. BACKGROUND
At the 2013 general election neither of the three main groupings, the centre-right led by Silvio Berlusconi, the centre-left led by Pier Luigi Bersani and the Five Star Movement (M5S) led by Beppe Grillo, won an outright majority in Parliament. After a failed attempt by Bersani, then-secretary of the Democratic Party (PD), to form a government and Giorgio Napolitano's re-election as President, Enrico Letta, Bersani's deputy, received the task of forming a grand coalition government. The Letta Cabinet consisted of the PD, Berlusconi's The People of Freedom (PdL) – which would be replaced by the New Centre-Right (NCD) in November 2013 –, Civic Choice (SC), the Union of the Centre (UdC), one Radical and three independents. Following the election of Matteo Renzi as PD secretary in December 2013, there were persistent tensions culminating in Letta's resignation in February 2014. Subsequently, Renzi formed a cabinet based on the same coalition (including the NCD). The new Prime Minister had a strong mandate from his party and was reinforced by the PD's strong showing in the 2014 European Parliament election and the election of Sergio Mattarella, a fellow Democrat, as President in 2015. Well into 2016, opinion polls registered the PD's strength and a growth of the M5S, Lega Nord (LN) and Brothers of Italy (FdI), while emphasizing a decline of Forza Italia (FI) – which had replaced the PdL in November 2013 –, the virtual disappearance of Civic Choice (SC) and the replacement of Left Ecology Freedom (SEL) with Italian Left (SI). In December 2016 Renzi was defeated in a constitutional referendum (59% to 41%). Under the reform, the Senate would have been composed of 100 members: 95 regional reprentatives and 5 presidential appointees. Following this defeat, Renzi stepped down as Prime Minister and was replaced by Paolo Gentiloni, another Democrat. In early 2017, some left-wing Democrats led by Bersani and Roberto Speranza launched, along with SI splinters, the Democratic and Progressive Movement (MDP). Also to the left of the PD, Giuliano Pisapia, a former Mayor of Milan, launched the Progressive Camp (CP), while, to the right, the NCD was transformed into Popular Alternative (AP). In April Renzi was re-elected secretary of the PD and thus candidate for Prime Minister. In May Salvini was re-elected federal secretary of the LN and launched his own campaign. In September Luigi Di Maio was selected as candidate for Prime Minister and "political head" of the M5S. POLITICAL GROUPS:
Government (381)
     PD 283
     MDP 43
     AP 23
     Demo.S–CD 12
     Misto 20 Opposition Parties (249)
     M5S 88
     FI 57
     LN 19
     SI–PO 17
     SC–ALA 15
     FdI 11
     Misto 42
__________________________________
COMMENTS: Polls have the M5S above the PD; however, Renzi's ebbing popularity coincides with growing friction inside his coalition, with a group of disaffected lawmakers from the small center-right NCD party threatening to join opposition ranks in a move that would make it extremely hard for the government to pass legislation in parliament. 
The so-called "disaffected lawmakers" are concerned that Renzi again as a PM would not be successful. There are talks of Pietro Grasso (now President of the Senate; a respected former Anti-Mafia prosecutor), that  plans to ally himself with Bersani (former head of the PD before Renzi), and form a new party with Grasso as head. Polls are already favorable to such an outcome. M5S has no clear ideological identity, it bases its appeal on the fight against Italy’s rampant corruption and pledges to break down the privileges of its political and business elite. But they are a bit late on that, as the Majors of Rome and Torino are embroiled in scandals and inability to govern. Likewise right after the recent stunning regional votes in favor of M5S, a series of corruption scandals emerged to prove that they are no saints either! 30-year-old Luigi Di Maio, who is widely expected to be the party’s candidate for prime minister at the next election; is gaffe-prone and totally unexperienced.  It seems a little too early for anyone to count their chickens yet!

I decresed the 201 and 340 bracket as I came to realization that both of the scenarios for M5S to attain such number of votes are much more unlikely.
Scenario 1 - M5S if forming a coalition might as well form a coalition with one of the larger parties to at least get majority of votes and be included in gorvernment formation.
Scenario 2 - This as I said is highly unlikely as it would have two unlikely events co-inciding - more than 90% of all votes cast during elections divided between two parties (M5S and a rival party most likely PD) and M5S not loosing to that rival party in vote count.

Based on the expected vs. real performance in the elections for other populist parties in Europe, the pre-elections polls has given them more votes than that the really get at the end. So, a moderate advance in seats instead of a massive grab is what we should expect.
difficulties on left side could increase chances against exit pölls from before...
I expect them around 80. Less than last time, because they are not so cool anymore. Still a force to be reckoned with.
I'm living in Switzerland, and live close to Italy, and I know losing popularity.

First I want to describe the assumptions based on which I have made my prediction:
1. The division of seat allocation of 630 Chamber of Deputies (CoD) is as follows:
a) 232 seats are directly elected in member districts
b) 386 are elected by national proportional representation.
c) 12 are elected by the Italians abroad. 2. Parties can choose to run as coalitions and these coalitions if winning more than 40% of vote will be allocated no fewer than 340 seats to achieve plurality in the CoD. 3. My assumption is that no party on it's own will win either absolute plurality (51% of the vote) or achieve 40% needed to secure the 340 seat allocation.
a) Based on polling data M5S YTD popularity has been 28,06%, followed by Democratic Party (27,56), Lega Nord (13,50%) and Forza Italia (13,04%). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Italian_general_election,_2018#2017
https://www.google.com/url?q=http://gfs.eiu.com/content/GetFile.ashx%3FRequest%3DFULL&sa=U&ved=0ahUKEwioloX2_d7XAhWhFZoKHTfLC70QFggFMAA&client=internal-uds-cse&cx=013751040265774567329:ylv-hrexwbc&usg=AOvVaw3uoUGX7_5CTHfNrZdI5gps 4. Luigi Di Maio has stated that M5S is willing to take other parties to coalition/have them support M5S, but will not give them any seats at the government. I assume that such a deal is not acceptable to other political parties who thus will be more hesitant to for a coalition with the MS5. Below are scenarios and explanations of my allocations of the percentage points in the way they are: Less than 50				5%
•	Would assume to happen only if there was a major political scandal implicating numerous M5S high level leaders (Di Maio, Grillo). Assuming also that such a scandal have to have to implicate the party leaders in allegations that contradict heavily against what the party has proposed to fight in its platfrom (e.g. large-scale corruption allegations, political collusion)
•	Another scenario would be a possible disintegration of the party into two or more competing parties. Between 50 and 87, inclusive		12%
•	Scenario 1: A political/personal scandal of one of the major leaders of the party.
•	Scenario 2: Highflying accendance of popularity of one of the rival larger parties (Democratic Party, People of Freedom, Northern League). This accendance of popularity would have to steal voters from the M5S. Between 88 and 200, inclusive		60%
•	Assumption that the party will not form a coalition.
•	Current popularity (average of polls) of M5S is 28,06% 
o	232 are directly elected in single member districts – 28,06% of it is 108
o	386 are elected by national proportional representation - 28,06% of it is 65
o	Sum of these 173
•	In 2013 elections 1 percentage point in votes won M5S 4,23 seats at CoD – if today it would get 28% of the vote it would add 12 seats to M5S – thus getting 121 seats.
•	Sum average of these two is  (173+121)/2= 147 Between 201 and 340, inclusive		13%
•	Scenario 1: Lower numbers of seats in this bracket could be reached when M5S would form a broad coalition with numerous other smaller parties.
•	Scenario 2: If M5S all vote percentage would be above 45% but it would still come second to another party that would get 46% of the total vote it seems possible that MS5 could barely achieve the 201 treashold.  For me a lot of complicated math, but scenario itself very unlikely :). More than 340				10%
•	Scenario 1: In case M5S would get 40% or more votes it would be allocated 54% of the seats in the parliament to have a majority. Throughout the year the polls have shown M5S popularity being between 25% and 32%, dropping slightly in the second half of the year.
•	Scenario 2: 40% of the total vote could also be achieved by forming coalitions with some of the larger parties. However this would be endorsing the „establishment“ parties that M5S has so far shunned and criticized. Thus unlikely.

Given the new electoral law and the current opinion polls, M5S is unlikely to fall below 100 seats, but would find it difficult to exceed 200 without coalition partners. So far no one has volunteered to partner with them, but of course there is plenty of time.
Somewhere around 25 % of seats feels right.
Past history and elections in France showing change is increasing
Populism losing steam in Europe and more level-headed leadership is able to resonate.

Populist parties have faced a hard time recently with elections, not being able to rally enough support to push them into power. A couple of exceptions include  AfD in Germany which recently won their first ever seats in Parliament and the ruling parties in Hungary and Poland. While I could predict the Five Star Movement increasing their share of seats slightly given how messy politics is in Italy right now, I have a hard time seeing any way for them to double their seats to more than 200.

I think M5S does better than its current position (87 seats) and they have improved significantly over the last four years. That being said I don't think they actually do as well their polls currently say (they're leading) because they seem like a protest vote and its much easier to protest between elections than at an election.
